title: What is the most reactive element? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, first of all, different elements react for different reasons, so it isn’t very fair to use a single scale of reactivity to judge all elements. However, the most important, is probably Electronegativity. The most electronegative element is Fluorine. It has an En of 4.0, which means that it will react with just about any non-inert substance in order to complete its outer shell. For this reason, hydrofluoric acid is one of the most acidic substances on earth, and Fluorine is rarely found in elemental form, as there is little in nature that can break a bond with Fluorine, without bonding to it itself. Of course on the other end of the spectrum, you have Caesium, the least electronegative element. Caesium really wants to get rid of its single valence electron, so that it’s outermost shell is filled. Caesium is extremely reactive, but most chemists would agree that Fluorine is even moreso. Diatomic Fluorine F2, is one of the weakest covalent bonds, and therefore is easily reactive with other substances to form fluoride salts and minerals, which make some of the strongest bonds. However, the reaction of fluoride with other substances is highly exothermique and dangerous, hence why several people died attempting to isolate Fluorine. Because of the extreme difficulty to metabolise Fluorine compounds, they are typically quite toxic to humans, and the chemical is sparsely used in biochemistry, despite the relative abundance of the chemical on earth.

Oxygen [edit:] When I answered originally I happened to be in a hurry and thinking along the lines of oxygen/oxidation/chemical bonds/aging. While oxygen does hold true in that context, it doesn't fit the bill across the board.  The question itself is a bit general, as different elements can be more (or less) reactive depending on the conditions and the other element present as well as a variety of other factors. So, on a Google adventure I went.  This is a small snippet from The Naked Scientist forum that I found enlightening. "Fluorine. It can burn substances which are generally thought of as nonflammable, such as glass, water and sand. It is the most electronegative of all of the reactive* elements and therefore has an extremely high attraction for electrons. As a consequence, compounds formed from fluorine are often quite stable, such as Teflon and fluorine salts. Lithium and potassium are also extremely reactive, but in a different way since they are electropositive instead of electronegative. Fluorine also reacts more readily than these two elements because it is a gas at standard conditions whereas the alkali metals are solids. Uranium and plutonium aren't even close. *Helium and neon have higher electronegativities, but are normally not reactive." [ Cited: http://www.thenakedscientists.com/forum/index.php?topic=49244.0 ]

Caesium and fluorine. Group I metals are the most reactive metals as they only have one electron in their outer shell which is easy to lose; they get more reactive as you go down the periodic table as the electron is further from the nucleus and shielded by the inner electrons. The halogens are the most reactive non-metals for the opposite reason - they only need one electron to fill their outer shell, and that is easiest for fluorine as it is the smallest and thus the incoming electron sees more of the nuclear charge. Francium is probably more reactive than caesium, but with a half-life of 22 minutes, we can't get enough to test.

For reactive elements, I will have to discuss the most reactive metal and the most reactive nonmetal because there are mainly two types of elements in the periodic table: metals and nonmetals (I’m not including metalloids because I do not want to have to find the most reactive and least reactive of the metalloids). The most reactive metal would be caesium. It is so reactive that it would ignite when exposed to air and explode when exposed to water. More information can be found here: Caesium - Wikipedia. The most reactive nonmetal would be flourine. Flourine is very reactive because it will react with mostly unreactive substances like glass fragments and water. More information about flourine is listed here: Fluorine - Wikipedia. I only answered this for educational purposes and I hope you do not use this knowledge with evil intentions in mind. Thank you for requesting me to answer this question and I hope you continue to learn more everyday.

Fluorine is the most reactive non metal, since it has the lowest electronegativity of all elements. This means it pulls you electrons towards it stronger than any other element. Looking at metals, theoretically the most reactive metal would be francium. However, as francium is highly radiactive with a very short half life, the most reactive metal is one up in the periodic table - caesium. Caesium has the highest electronegativity of all stable metals. Caesium is also far more reactive than lithium. By dropping each group 1 element on water, the reactions become more violent. Lithium merely fizzes whilst sodium fizzes a little more violently. Going down through potassium and rubidium the reactions become more explosive. Caesium is the most explosive of the group when mixed with water.

It depends on what they are reacting with. If isolated atoms probably N forming N2 the strongest covalent bond or perhaps W tungsten the highest melting metal. If reaction between 2 elements it depends. The EMF tables are in aqueous solutions so they might not apply to neat reactions and there are mechanistic hurdles to overcome. I will still give the nod to fluorine because of its weak bond in F2 and it's small ion size. The cation is more difficult Cs is a good choice but the larger ion size might lower lattice energy so Sr or Ba might compete. heat of formation of BaF2 is more than twice that of CsF while SrF2 is half so let's try the reaction of Ba and F2. LiF has a higher heat of formation than CsF but may be kinetically restrained by a higher ionization potential.

Fluorine. It can burn substances which are generally thought of as nonflammable, such as glass, water and sand. It is the most electronegative of all of the reactive* elements and therefore has an extremely high attraction for electrons. As a consequence, compounds formed from fluorine are often quite stable, such as Teflon and fluorine salts. Lithium and potassium are also extremely reactive, but in a different way since they are electropositive instead of electronegative. Fluorine also reacts more readily than these two elements because it is a gas at standard conditions whereas the alkali metals are solids. Uranium and plutonium aren't even close. *Helium and neon have higher electronegativities, but are normally not reactive. Hope it helps…

Fluorine: This close to completing an octet and simultaneously pairing (pairing: 2 electrons, one with an ‘up’ spin, and the other with a ‘down’) all electrons in shell #2 when reacting (similar reason to why neon is the least reactive). Electrons tightly brought in by nucleus as they lack energy to be ‘free’ (thus a small radius), unlike a metal. FTW, the maximum number of electrons a shell can have is 2n^2, where n is the shell number. In those shells, the electrons are paired inside orbitals (basically energy levels and the different ways electron ‘clouds’ are ‘shaped’) with each orbital containing 4 more electrons than the former (applying to within one shell). In other words, arranged in this way*: 2n+4(n-1)th triangular number**. Let’s say that n=2. Substitute n for 2. 2*2+4*[(2(2–1))/2]=8. 2+6=8. 8 is the number of electrons which chemical elements usually attempt to hold in their valence shell and the maximum shell #2 can hold! Fluorine has two shells! *Yes, I do realise that it simplifies to 2n^2. **f(n)=[n+(n+1)]/2

There are two probable answers one with reference to metals and other with non metals within metals cesium is most reactive as it's ionisation is easy and among non metals fluorine is most reactive due to its high electronegativity there may be other possible answers too it depends actually what is being asked which medium is taken, which type of reaction is observed, etc. Plz upvote the answer if you are satisfied.

The most reactive metal is Cesium.( Francium isn't considered as it is radioactive). Cesium has the least ionization energy, so it is the easiest for its atom to lose it's seingle valence electron. The most reactive non-metal is Fluorine. Fluorine only needs one electron for its stability, and due to its small size, the incoming electron is easily attracted. Cesium belongs to Group 1, period 6 and Fluorine belongs to Group 17, period 2. Hope it helps.

Caesium is the most reactive metal . It rapidly reacts with water to form caesium hydroxide and hydrogen gas. Fluorine is the most reactive non metal since it is highly electronegative. It even reacts with glass, water and sand. Fluorine reacts explosively with hydrogen even in the dark and at low temperature. It reacts violently with water forming hydrogen fluoride, and liberates oxygen which is highly charged with ozone. It also reacts with sulphur, selenium, and tellurium, which melt and ignite in the gas, forming halides. Fluorine reacts violently with water forming hydrogen fluoride, and liberates oxygen which is highly charged with ozone. It not only reacts with water and liberates oxygen, but also reacts with atmospheric moisture and liberates oxygen.

Francium, a metal in the Lithium Sodium Potassium (“alkali metals”) series. There is probably a video of its reaction in water. Yes there are several. Some show the series, but chicken out at Francium, very sensibly. Check out “Brainiac” on the subject, but be sure to stand well back from the computer screen!!! I now find that Francium has a half-life of 22 minutes (MINUTES) so it is not a subject for study. For Francium read Caesium! The reason for this reactivity is that each of the metals has a single electron in its outer electron shell, which the atom is happy to shed to leave a nice neat complete outside shell. The further down the series you go the more loosely the extra electron is bound and the keener the atom is to lose it. Have fun . . .

For Electropositive elements, Caesium leads the group. It is an Alkali Metal with very large size resulting in easy Ionisation. Francium is even more reactive but it is an artificially created element which decays radioactively before it gets a chance to react chemically. Talking about Electronegative elements, the answer is Fluorine. It the the most Electronegative element in the world. It reacts with Inert gases. Fluorine is so strongly Electronegative that even Chlorine (a fellow halogen) behaves as a metal when bonded with it (creating ClF7).

it depends on whether u mean metals or non metals……in case of nonmetals..Fluorine is most reactive..while Cesium in case of metals…but it entirely depends upon the type of reaction elements are undergoing…..for example..in case of hydrolysis..lithim salts are more reactive becus of the huge hydration enthalpy….but cesium compounds are also so electropositive that they can react with metals like Gold..to form compounds like CsAu (Cesium Auride) which ionises as Cs+ + Au-

Fluorine is the most reactive element yet discovered and much ahead of others. Ceasium is the direct opposite of fluorine .It is very reactive but unlike fluorine it gives away electrons. But then why is fluorine so ahead of ceasium? Ans: because fluorine in majority of conditions will rip away the opposite's electron but ceasium can only give 1 electron if the opposite has vacant orbital space. Thus ripping away is dependent only on the ripper but pushing depends on both the pusher and the one who is pushed. Thus fluorine reacts with much more particles than ceasium ,even 0 group's!!! Cheers ! Upvote if helpful

It depends on what you mean by reactive. The most reactive metal is lithium as measured by the energy released when combined with an oxidizer. Conversely fluorine is the most reactive when combined with a reducing agent. When considering the atomic mass of the atoms then hydrogen produces the most energy per unit weight. So you want to be a bit more specific but you probably want lithium.

I personally don't like the term but there are two main ways that reactivity is taught at a young age. The first is in terms of the reactivity series. This shows the order of elements in terms of their reactivity. This just refers to how reactive they are towards water and weak acids. For example:  S Of course every element reacts differently to every other element, compound etc. This isn't really very useful. A more general way of thinking about it might be in terms of electronegativity. I.e. the more desperate an element is for an electron(s), or is desperate to get rid of an electron (s) the more reactive it is.

This is a controversial question, since to decide a single most reactive element comparisons would have to be made across various groups, which is not preferred due to different reaction properties of metals and non metals. Among metals, caesium is most reactive. Among non metals, fluorine is the most reactive element.

In my opinion, it would be fluorine. It will react with almost everything, even noble gases like Xe. The reaction is very favourable. It can be stored in only a limited amount of select materials and is very scary to handle. It is so reactive that I even made a joke out of it. (If you wanna know, ask for it in the comments section) You could also check out videos on YouTube, particularly

Cesium and Fr is the most reactive elements in the periodic table. These are most reactive due to its bigger size in periodic table than any other element. So due to its larger size it is very easy to disturb it's electronic cloud by other elements, that's why we said that Cs and Fr are most reactive elements in the periodic table.

Usually atoms with either one electron deficient to reach stable state or atom having one electron in excess to reach stable state are more reactive than any other elements in their respective rows in periodic table. By this logic  group 1 or group 7 are more reactive elements. Now in same group reactivity decreases as we move down .Thus  1st element in group 1 (neglect H) is K and 1st element in group 7 is F are more reactive elements with their counter parts .

The most reactive elements in The Periodic Table of Elements are “ Caesium and fluorine. Group I metals are the most reactive metals as they only have one electron in their outer shell which is easy to lose; they get more reactive as you go down the periodic table as the electron is further from the nucleus and shielded by the inner electrons. “

Answer is the cesium because most reactive species in periodic table are group one elements and going down the group the reactivity of elements increases so, the cesium as the last element group is most reactive. We don't consider francium because it is radioactive element. If the francium will not be a radioactive element then the most reactive element may consider as most reactive. Net result : Cesium is most reactive element.

Fluorine & LithiumThe chemical "royalty" of the periodic table. Why you ask???In my opinion, the reactivity of an element, would be the ability of a single element to displace into a compound, and its in ability to be displaced by another element when in a compound. So......In terms of elements displacing cations Lithium is King, no other element is capable of displacing Lithium, and Lithium will displace any and all cations. The same is true of Fluorine, no other element is capable of displacing a Fluoride anion, and Fluorine, Queen of all elements will displace any other anion "in a he Continue Reading
Fluorine is the most reactive non radioactive element on periodic table. It exists in gaseous form at room temperature and even reacts with glass. So it is almost impossible to store it in pure form.

A good indicator of reactivity is an elements electronegativity. The elements with the highest and lowest values are typically the most reactive. Flourine is the most reactive on the negative side, while Caesium and Francium are disputed as the most reactive on the positive side as Francium’s short half life make measurements difficult but is most likely more electropositive than Caesium.

Alkali metals (situated far away from transitional metals and noble gases) are the most reactive elemental group. Cesium is second from the bottom of this group, with 6 electron shells, so it fits all the characteristics of a reactive atom, therefore making it the most reactive element.

Q. What is the most reactive common element in the world? Define “common.” Reactivity also depends on the chemical state; for example, oxygen is completely inert if it’s incorporated into silicates. But the most common element that’s present in a highly-reactive state in nature is oxygen. Because of photosynthetic organisms, which are constantly spitting out corrosive, dangerous oxygen gas, the highly-reactive chemical form O2 is present all over the world in large quantities.

According to the reactivity series reactive elements include potassium, sodium, calcium, magnesium and a few more. Reactive means the element has a tendency to lose electrons. It has a tendency to lose electrons because it wants to gain an octet or duplet valence shell structure and be stable resembling that of noble gases. Polar substances are more reactive than non polar substances, arising from differences in electronegativity. A huge difference in electronegativities causes a substance to be reactive.

Flourine is the most reactive element as it is also the most electronegative out of all the elements…as it needs only one electron to complete it's octate it reacts quickly with other elements and thus achieve noble gas configuration…

Fluorine (F) is the first element in the Halogen group (group 17) in the periodic table. It is the most electronegative element, given that it is the top element in the Halogen Group, and therefore is very reactive. It is a nonmetal, and is one of the few elements that can form diatomic molecules (F2).
